Governor John Bel Edwards
March 13 at 1:07 PM ·

Today, I signed a proclamation that immediately halts any gathering of more than 250 people until Monday, April 13, closes all K-12 public schools statewide effective Monday, March 16 and also moves upcoming state elections.

We are at an inflection point now and we are going to take bold action to minimize the further spread of this illness. That is why I am issuing this order today, ending all events of more than 250 people, closing our schools, and reducing the amount of face-to-face public interaction at state government buildings.

In a separate executive order I will grant Secretary of State Kyle Ardoin’s request to move our upcoming elections for April and May to June and July. The limits on gatherings of 250 people or more statewide is based on federal CDC guidance given the community spread which we are currently experiencing. These steps are necessary to protect the health and safety of the people of Louisiana from the risk of COVID-19.

On Thursday morning, Nov. 29th, the Claiborne Office of Homeland Security conducted a mock mass casualty drill as a part of the Claiborne Memorial Medical Center reaccreditation process. Participating in the mock motor vehicle collision involving multiple teenagers were Claiborne Parish Sheriff’s Office, Homer Police Department, Homer Fire Department, and Pafford EMS.

Students from Homer High School played the role of patients. The students are in an EMR (Emergency Medical Responder) class at the school and included Kameria Alford, Kenyon Banks, Tracy Hampton, Amber Mack, and Shannon Turner.

The five patients were assessed and transported from the MVC scene at Mayfield Park by Pafford EMS to the Claiborne Memorial Medical Center in three waves, providing the hospital an unannounced opportunity to practice their plan for processing simultaneously multiple patients with serious injuries. All five patients “lived!"

The mock mass casualty drill was a resounding success.

From the desk of Superintendent William Kennedy:

Yesterday, the Louisiana Department of Education released the 2017-18 school performance scores (SPS). We are now operating on a new School Performance Score scale where the goal is “Mastery.” Basic is no longer equivalent to a score of “A.” The overall SPS of schools throughout the state dropped an average of around 17 points. However, Two of our Claiborne Parish schools actually grew a letter grade moving up to “B” status. Only 3% of the schools in the state moved up a letter grade. Summerfield High School and Haynesville Jr/Sr High both gained “B” status! I am very proud of the efforts put forth by the students, faculty and staff, as well as the administration. I look forward to continued growth of all of our schools and hopefully will be able to congratulate some schools next year for gaining “A” status.

CONGRATULATIONS AND THANKS for all of your hard work!

Tuesday March 20th, there will be a parish wide event held at the Claiborne Parish Library in Homer. Trained representatives will help parents of graduating seniors complete their child's FAFSA application. This event will be held from 4-7pm Tuesday. Please bring your 2016-17 year tax information with you when you come. The FAFSA will allow your child to apply for Tops and other financial aid necessary for 4 year college, community colleges, and technical schools. Completing a FAFSA application or signing a waiver is a new State mandated requirement for your child to graduate. To sign a waiver or for further questions please call your child's school. Thank you.
